Introduction .Measurement of D - dimer concentration in the blood is a valuable tool in the diagnostic investigation of patients with suspected pulmonary embolism .A D - dimer concentration below the conventional cut - off point of 500 μg / l combined with a " low / intermediate " or " unlikely " clinical probability can safely rule out the diagnosis in about 30 % of patients with suspected pulmonary embolism . 1 2 3 However , the D - dimer concentration increases with age and its specificity for embolism decreases , which makes the test less useful to exclude pulmonary embolism in older patients .
